title: Regarding the priest in Syndra's story...
body: What would happen if he actually helped Syndra to control/strengthen her power? Would she turn out good?

replies.body:
Good and evil are relative... ;-) My hunch is that she would never be particularly popular with this power, in Ionia... and so, they're going to see it all as a bad thing.

But, as I said in another thread, imagine if she'd been born in Noxus. She'd be a hugely respected and powerful mage, probably on the front lines of the military.

The truly scary/evil/out of control Syndra would have been one born in Demacia. She'd be public enemy number one, there.

Oh, no.  The worst one would have been in Shurima, no doubt.  Both sides would offer her alliance, but she would refuse, too proud for anything less than absolute power.  She’d either wait for them to be exhausted from fighting each other and seize power or, in  frustration at not being able to take over the region, resolve to kill _everyone_, one tribe, village, and town at a time.

And were Syndra about to be defeated, she would seek Malzahar and offer to tear open and empower the largest Void Rift she could, just to spitefully destroy the world she already hates.

Edit: Definitely more evil than Xerath.  She wants to rule the world only to make everyone suffer as much as possible until she grows bored and then kills them all.

It's really interesting to me that a lot of people see her as pure evil, while others are like NO! WHERE'S THE NUANCE?! etc.

I'd always consider whose POV a story or bio is being told from, and why. To Sirik, Syndra looks like a dangerous thing that needs to be destroyed. To Okin, she's something that could be used for another purpose. The narrative of the story is from Sirik's perspective, so that's our primary view.

A villain for villainy's sake, who has no motive beyond being a villain, cannot last under scrutiny. But they can always be a villain from someone else's POV.

> [{quoted}](name=Scathlocke,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=V6wAAo9d,comment-id=000000010000,timestamp=2018-08-06T23:00:33.595+0000)

She seems like a flat character to me, especially with what appears to be homicidal rage at a young age.  It makes her seem like just the sort of apocalyptic sociopath that the spirit of Ionia itself might want to contain.

> I'd always consider whose POV a story or bio is being told from, and why. To Sirik, Syndra looks like a dangerous thing that needs to be destroyed. To Okin, she's something that could be used for another purpose. The narrative of the story is from Sirik's perspective, so that's our primary view.

Both of them see Syndra as a dangerous thing.  Sirik wants to kill her before the Noxians release her; Okin wants to ship her to Noxus and let her loose there before the Noxians unleash her in Ionia.  

> A villain for villainy's sake, who has no motive beyond being a villain, cannot last under scrutiny. But they can always be a villain from someone else's POV.

Never underestimate the appeal—or importance—of having unabashed good and bad guys in your story.  They serve as universal protagonists and antagonists while also clearly morally contrasting every character on the moral spectrum between them.

The light that shines in Lux and bottomless abomination of Nocturne are both worthy subjects of writing.  Just knowing the right thing to do is difficult, much less doing it.  Her struggles are worth writing about.  Likewise, being the most terrifying thing in Runeterra is both nothing easy and tells us about our own fears.

Sometimes, characters are best left unsympathetic.  The experience of a emotionless, predatory mind that wishes only our destruction is a profoundly unsettling one, and it’s a fantasy common to many villains throughout literature.  We don’t always want to even try to understand the bad guy, and sometimes we want to play someone who has nothing for us to understand but the fear he delivers.

Likewise, not every character needs a moral flaw.  A transcendent sense of moral duty and the courage and power to enact it are revered in history and just as common as the black-hearted villain as fantasies.  Admiring a champion for their selflessness, bravery, and determination, along with their relentless and clear-minded devotion to ethics, is just as moving as loathing their villainy.

Hence the need for wholesome champions like Taliyah, Orianna, Lux, Ashe, Braum, or Nunu; and also the need for complete monsters like Draven, Nocturne, or the Voidborn.  An out-of-control mage bent on destruction, especially as a foil to Ryze, would make an excellent character if explored, especially in relation to others and their environment.

Do you consider the Voidborn evil? I've never gotten that impression - they don't possess any concept of good or evil for themselves, so they aren't taking decisions or moral positions.

Is a wolf evil, if it kills and eats a sheep? What about the ocean that drowns a fisherman who was trying to feed his family?

(Also, Draven is just a celebrity in a culture that venerates skill and strength - are MMA fighters evil? They beat each other up for entertainment and prizes...)

I'm always really wary of ascribing concrete definitions of morality to any character, because it is not universal and cannot be quantified. There's that whole description of Star Wars, like "Young rural farmboy is radicalised into illegal religious sect, joins a terrorist group and destroys a military installation" sort of thing. Is Luke Skywalker actually a hero at all? THOUSANDS DIED etc...

They want to destroy the world and are hated and feared by everyone except a mind-controlled prophet, seem self-aware, and enjoy it.  If they’re not evil, then who is?  Also, see Nocturne.
 
> (Also, Draven is just a celebrity in a culture that venerates skill and strength - are MMA fighters evil? They beat each other up for entertainment and prizes...)

I can actually talk about this, since I was reading about Roman Gladiators, the closest thing to Draven, on Wikipedia the other night.  They were celebrities only on-stage, but off-stage even the greatest gladiators had the lowest status of society, slavery, and were reviled by all.  They weren’t even buried with other slaves.

Even in Rome, an expansionist military aristoctracy that venerated skill and strength and was infamous for the depravity of its imperial days, maiming and killing other people for entertainment was nothing to be proud of.  Indeed, gladiators themselves were often allowed to live if they fought bravely, both because sponsors wanted to save money and the crowd often disapproved of killing them.

Now, just imagine Draven.  He’s not a gladiator—he’s an executioner.  He kills helpless people and laughs as he does it.  His only motivations are fame, money, and bloodthirsty sadism.  The regular, gleeful, spectacular slaughter of condemned prisoners before the cheers of a genuinely adoring crowd is something largely unheard of in history.

Public executions were usually done to frighten the populace, rather than entertain them.  Even when they were, they were reserved for objects of hatred, and usually by some mechanical means or by using animals.  And still, the executioners were so despised that they often wore masks and had trouble in their personal lives.

Think of the inhuman depths to which a society would have to sink before someone like Draven could exist.  Its population would have to generally enjoy the sight of helpless people being chopped into pieces, not out of rage or hatred or indignation, but just because they can be, and vicariously enjoy doing it themselves.  There’s no contest to see who’s stronger or better, per Noxian culture, only the vicious exercise of power already had.

There’s someone selling tickets to those shows, and there are people buying them, implying that the following conversation would have to be common in Noxus:

“Come get your Draaaaaven tickets!  Come get your Draaaaaven tickets—three executions today!  Free drinks, courtesy of _Drekan Drinks_ beverage company!  Come get your tickets!”

“Dad!  Dad!  I heard that Draven cuts ‘em clean in half!  I wanna go see!”

“Well. that’s not just up to me, sport!  Ask your mother, too.”

“Oh, darling, certainly.  I loved watching those shows with my friends as a girl.  It’s worth every penny to see the smile—and the blood—on his face!”

None of its participants could believably have any redeeming qualities.  Any shred of decency, much less compassion, would render a Draven show unpalatable.  But these would have to be average Noxians rather than scum dredged up from the bottom of their society.

So the average Noxian would have to be essentially monstrous, with Draven just being the most open and accomplished of them all.  The pair of feet with the most heads rolling around it, if you will .  I don’t see how “evil” doesn’t enter the picture.

> I'm always really wary of ascribing concrete definitions of morality to any character, because it is not universal and cannot be quantified. There's that whole description of Star Wars, like "Young rural farmboy is radicalised into illegal religious sect, joins a terrorist group and destroys a military installation" sort of thing. Is Luke Skywalker actually a hero at all? THOUSANDS DIED etc...

I am cheeky enough to claim that you don’t want to make someone’s champion the bad guy and alienate them, and that you can’t admit this because it would open the door to endless questions about who falls on which side of what moral line.  I am _also_ cheeky enough to try to make you choose between defending the indefensible and opening that very door which I suspect you would rather keep shut.  

Maybe even these thoughts alone, toward someone who’s taken the time out of their Monday to reply to me, make _me_ evil?  Muahaha. >:3

But let me turn your example around: do Darth Vader lovers really see him as the white-knight hero of his story, or do they embrace his villainy?

So one note on Draven's lore. It might be ever so slightly outdated at this point. Remember Riven's expectations of a trial were that she would have to fight someone to prove who was right. From this bit I have to assume that the high executioner of Noxus isn't an executioner in the typical sense. 

Draven is likely no longer killing defenseless people, but sort of fights as an embodiment of Noxian law in glorious arena combat. In Noxus's "might makes right" kind of culture Draven essentially represents the might of the ruling government against criminals.

This would also explain why Urgot may have been ousted since the high executioner has to believe in the rules they are upholding.

It's still not clean, and flies against our moral standards, but it makes sense in the context of what we know about Noxus.

No idea what happens if Draven loses.

That’s an interesting point!  Still, even as a Gladiator, Draven would have been hated off-stage.  Per my other post, Noxians would have to be monsters to generally find the killing of helpless people entertaining and admire the people who do it.

IF I'm right then a Noxian executioner actually has only their title and the fact that they do kill criminals in common with an executioner, and the only thing they have in common with a gladiator is that they're fighting in an arena. Noxian Executioners would essentially be fighting in the place of anyone who would fight for the the rule that was broken. Which would be quite a few people in a society like Noxus. If some guy goes around kicking people's dogs then instead of getting lynch mobbed they fight the Executioner. The people that go to the arena and watch the fight are the people that believe you shouldn't go around kicking dogs. The Executioner is just doing what any law abiding Noxian would be expected to do if there were no executioner.

So Imo Noxian Executioners are less about entertainment or doing a dirty job, and more about keeping a society like Noxus organised so fights aren't breaking out on the streets constantly. So I would expect the local Executioner to be sort of revered as a town leader. If you want a law passed or changed you either have to convince the Executioner or get a new one.

All that said I expect that in most cases it's a lot like ritual combat, the exception being Draven's fights. People that attend other Executions are likely to show up to it in the same way people would attend a trial, but where Draven has turned it into a spectacle it is a bit more bloodthirsty and likely very controversial even among Noxians.

(The Fleshing of course is a totally different mater, but can sort of be explained by [Life is a Battle](https://universe.leagueoflegends.com/en_US/region/noxus/?mv=image-gallery) in the Environments section)

No doubt, but his current lore still his pre-retcon lore. Pre-retcon Noxus **_was_** the evil faction.  However Riot has been slowly changing that so that it is more perspective based.

In effect I'm arguing that when Riot updates Draven's lore his space as an "executioner" is going to be very changed. I am basing those theories on a single one of Riven's lines in her story, and trying to think of how that fits with Noxian society. (so it's not a super concrete theory)

Most of the old champs in the game were written as evil or good, but that's boring so I'm glad it's been getting phased out.

Noxus has never been the evil faction. I don't know what lore you've read, but nothing ever indicated that. You're simply making grossly inaccurate presumptions on your own part based on personally held inadequacies.

This is a good take.  To argue that Syndra wouldn't appear villainous to others, even the Syndra many in this thread seem to have in their head (which is totally valid, of course), is a little silly.  A sympathetic Syndra who kills a man and expresses a want for boundless power would at the very least seem both dangerous & selfish to some, which, if she really is so strong, could be someone anyone would want contained for the sake of the world, even if it's wrong to treat her in such a way on its own.

Hey do you guys think you'll ever talk about how runeterra magic works? I know this is like, super super niche and maybe unnecessary to know, but if a mage practiced at different kinds of magic could they learn other kinds, the same way say in Warcraft you can learn frost fire arcane shadow etc? 

Or is it like, you're born with one kind of magic, and its like being a mutant in the X-Men. Seems more that route so far of course, but on the other hand maybe all the mages in league are just doing the naruto thing, where they COULD learn other stuff, if they had the right teachers, but they specialize in their own powers anyway to hone in on what they're good at. I wonder how much output variety someone as practiced as ryze could actually have if he wanted to

Ryze was shown from all his piecies of lore put together to have A LOT of spells. I made a list once about all his abilities shown but I just realised it's incomplete... Ryze is one powerfull mage. Also Ryze is Also indirectly buffed by his exposure to the World Runes and a part of their energy flows through him.

Ryze certainly began to explain the nature and uses of magic in 'From the Ashes' - from an in-world perspective. I don't know that we have any need to explain it in an encyclopedia-style way, but it's a fascinating topic.

Personally, I'd like to see more of Ryze teaching Kegan! :-)
What do you consider to be an encyclopedia style explanation? Isn't the Vastaya discovery story an example of that?

Santangelo's field journal? No, that's a characterful exploration, in the setting. We love those, because they help build the world in an authentic way.

I meant more like an RPG sourcebook that explains the "science" of how magic works - we won't be doing that for Universe, any time soon. :-)
Is Ryze slightly powered by the Runes then? Like a sort of passive radiation from them that resulted in buffs to his power and slightly altered biology?
Well, when people want an explanation on how magic, and other things work, we don't necessarily mean sourcebooks. A story about an Ionian teacher training a student works as well.

First of all, wow.  A rioter replied. Second of all, I wish that too but I would also like to know the story of how Ryze became an arch-mage  (In case he didn't become one the very moment he killed his master)

Feels like they are trying to imply she was already way off the dark end by the time she got there and it only grow worse which made the priest unable to really actively interact with her which in turn made things even worse.

Then the ...land itself? Pulls her down and imprisons her forcing her to face her nightmares endlessly.....yeah how was this supposed to help again? 


It feels like they were kinda trying waaay too hard to just stack everything against her to make her this villain with a tragic backstory, feels really forced.

> Then the ...land itself? Pulls her down and imprisons her forcing her to face her nightmares endlessly.....yeah how was this supposed to help again? 

Looks like putting people in existentially horrifying and totally escapable prisons isn't just a Targon thing after all.

True that, and i am fairly sure that everyone felt that was a really dirty move so i wonder if someone will really think it was alright to do so with Syndra x)

Heck her very name as off now is just a insult from the people she was with.

Like villains are fine, having someone just lose their marbles and become a nutcase like Jhin did is one thing, or poke a weird magic artifact and go nuts like brand.

Or get PTSD, void corruption and hundreds of years of torture in Aatrox´s case to become a crazed monster only looking to die. 

But writing up a story where someone literally has repeated worst case scenarios happen in a row without a break followed by her finally escaping her nightmare only to realize someone is trying to strangle her to death? Her being called the monster and evil one right after that too?

Despite only really being a abused child that was never taught better?

Feels so forced that i dont even know what x)

The really weird thing about all of this "let's put our powerful foes in eternal torture prisons and cross our fingers that they don't get out" business is that it's not only unethical, it's ineffective.

 With Syndra and the Darkin, we've got stories of horrific prisons that, if anything, make their inhabitants even worse than before. Then they inevitably get out of said prisons and now they're everyone's problem.

Even from a completely heartless standpoint, imprisoning Syndra or the Darkin was an incredibly stupid move. It only delayed a problem instead of actually solving it.

So yeah, the Spirit of Ionia made an astonishingly bad call with Syndra.

Yeah, i mean in a very extreme way someone might justify what happened to the Darkin as justice for the people they killed and the lands they destroyed, they were conscious off their actions and did things anyway.

However torturing for hundreds of years and turning them into semi immortal monsters  is not the way to punish a already twisted demigod, that is just going to backfire. 


And while what happened to Syndra wasnt quite so extreme, she wasnt forced to face a hundred years long torture session on end, just the same one over and over with her memories suppressed between each time.

But i agree that it makes no sense to just force her to relive everything over and over with no memories off it in a dream- 

Like, any point is just lost when she loses her memories off the previous times.


So more than a bad call, it almost feels deliberately done, thats how little sense it all makes.

I don't think there's a lot that could be done with her. I mean, her power is derived from the land itself, and it draws into her at an alarming speed when she uses it. She sucks the life essence from the world by simply accessing her magic, so I think the reason the priest dampened her magic was to prevent further damage to the world. 

I mean hell, when she had a fit of rage after killing him, the land itself was like "NAH BITCH, THIS HAS GOT TO STOP," and _Ionia_ itself reached up, grabbed her, and put her in stasis mode.
Syndra will be Syndra justiciar if she control her power ! Maybe Syndra is going to chose her own path. Staying a dark mage or evolve in something between light and darkness.
